lines.text: [first lines]
[Clarice's friend honks his car horn]
We'll be right out! Hurry, Clarice, the horses are frothing!
Snap it up, Paula!
Hold still, baby.
Well, we're going to be late.
[to her date, referring to Paula]
She never goes to Mardi Gras.

[to Clarice's date]
She squirts seltzer bottles. Watch it.
Now behave yourself or I'll come and chaperone.
Oh, why don't you, Paula?
Go ahead, Paula. If you swung from a chandelier once in your life, maybe you'd forget this trip to the islands.
Crazy youngsters.
As one old graybeard to another, what do you do for rheumatism?
[Clarice and her escort kiss passionately]
Stop it! Stop it! It's time you two were in bed.

[coyly]
Why, Paula...
Oh, ah, I-I didn't mean...

[to Clarice's date]
Now you'll just have to go. That's all there is to the matter.
[Paula shoves the man out the door]
Wh-where'd the nice man go? Nice man...
[drunkenly whistles as if calling a dog]
Where's the nice man?
Clarice...
C'mon, nice man...
I've been handling Mr. Cormack's mistakes for years. I believe I'm competent.
Now, baby, are you sure you didn't get into any trouble?
Aw, no no no, no trouble. First we went to Oglethorpe's - we all went to Oglethorpe's for supper...
Yes.
And then we went dancing at Bell Tavern, then we got married and then we all went for breakfast.
What did you say?
I said we all went for breakfast.
I ought to divorce you!
No, Mr. Cormack, you can't divorce me and you can't bawl me out because I'm not your wife. Just let me be a lesson for you. I'm the sort of thing that happens when you start proposing between drinks.

You married my sister and you can't blame her because, well, you're nice enough to make any woman forget she has a husband and you can't blame me because I was trying to save my sister from jail. Why, you can't even blame Andrews because she was his wife! So you see, Mr. Cormack, it was all your fault.
[Clarice snaps her fingers and Andrews follows her out the door]
Just like a poodle!
